newsitem.title: CHINA: China economy seen entering smooth growth period.
newsitem.headline: China economy seen entering smooth growth period.

text.p: China's economy has entered a period of steady growth and is set to achieve a "soft landing" in 1996 after years of overheated expansion, the official Xinhua news agency said.
Economic growth rates were expected to be higher than price increases this year for the first time since 1993, Xinhua quoted State Statistical Bureau economist Qiu Xiaohua as saying.
Commodity prices rose a year-on-year 6.6 percent in the January-September period, while the economic growth rate stayed at around 10 percent, the agency said late on Sunday.
"The goal of 'soft-landing' could be basically achieved within 1996...," it said.
A bumper harvest, growing industrial output and reasonable investment in fixed assets all suggested a rosy economic outlook, Xinhua said.
China's foreign exchange reserves were expected to hit $100 billion by the end of the year, thanks to the rapid inflow of foreign capital, it said.

Total turnover of retail consumer goods was expected to grow 20 percent year-on-year in the second half, while average incomes were expected to grow by between four and five percent compared with last year, it said.
Consumption was expected to grow by eight percent compared with 1995, it said, but added economic problems such as growing redundancies from loss-making state enterprises remained to be dealt with.
